question: Most common cause of shunt infection following a Ventriculo-Peritoneal shunt is:
exp: V-P Shunt: Medical device that relieves pressure on the brain by draining the extra CSF from brain into peritoneum. Used to treat Hydrocephalus Major complications of V-P shunt: Occlusion --> characterized by headache, papilledema, emesis, mental status changes. Bacterial infection --> characterized by fever, headache, meningismus. MCC --> Staph epidermidis

question: All of the following are true about Dandy Walker malformation EXCEPT?
exp: Dandy Walker malformation: It is d/t failure of opening of foramen of Magendie Results in balooning of posterior wall of 4th ventricle to form a cyst in posterior fossa. Associated with other cerebral & cerebellar anomalies. - Clinical features: Delayed development, spasticity and cerebellar ataxia.
opa: It is due to the failure of opening of foramen of Magendie
opb: 4th ventricle forms a cyst in the posterior fossa
opd: Delayed development and spasticity may be seen.

question: Mac Ewan sign is seen in:
exp: - In Hydrocephalus, percussion of the skull might produce a cracked pot sound or Mac Ewen sign, indicating separation of the sutures. - Large head with venous prominences & SETTING SUN SIGN are also seen

question: Which of the following is not a cause of communicating hydrocephalus?
exp: - Vein of Galen causes Obstructive or Non-communicating hydrocephalus. Causes: COMMUNICATING HYDROCEPHALUS NON-COMMUNICATING HYDROCEPHALUS C - Choroid plexus papilloma A - Achondroplasia M - Meningeal malignancy or metastasis P - Post hemorrhagic M - Mass lesion (ICSOL) A - Abscess A - Aqueductal stenosis A - Arnold Chiari malformation D - Dandy walker malformations H - Hematoma I - Infections (Toxoplasma, mumps, Neurocysticercosis) V - Vein of Galen malformations

question: Which is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborn?
exp: - Ventriculomegaly is seen in neonates with hydrocephalus. - Obstructive or noncommunicating hydrocephalus develops most commonly in children d/t abnormality of aqueduct of Sylvius or a lesion in the fouh ventricle. - Nonobstructive or communicating hydrocephalus most commonly follows a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is usually a result of intraventricular hemorrhage in a premature infant.

question: The following are recognized signs and symptoms of raised intracranial tension in a 9-month-old infant, EXCEPT:
exp: - Papilledema is usually not seen in infancy & neonates, as the fontanelle are open. - Signs & symptoms of raised ICP: Headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, progressing to neurological deficits & coma Chronically raised ICP before closure of sutures results in increased head size & hydrocephalus presenting as Bilateral sunsetting Tense bulging anterior fontanelle Hypertension & bradycardia 6th cranial nerve palsy - false localizing sign

question: Arnold Chiari malformation is characterized by all except:
exp: - Hypoplasia of cerebellar vermis is seen in DANDY WALKER SYNDROME: Arnold Chiari malformation It is the most common malformation of the posterior fossa and hindbrain. It consists of herniation of the cerebellar tonsils though the foramen magnum. Often, there is associated abnormality of the bones of the skull base leading to a small posterior fossa Type I typically produces symptoms during adolescence or adult life and is usually not associated with hydrocephalus. Type II Chiari malformation is characterized by progressive hydrocephalus with a myelomeningocele.
opd: Adulthood syndrome not associated with hydrocephalus
